title: Before 2 June 2018, will the Trump administration exempt Mexico from steel tariffs set to be imposed on 1 June 2018?
preds: https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/05/hits-eu-mexico-canada-steel-aluminum-tariffs-180531134948849.html Goes into effect tomorrow, but article says this “ends a two-month exemption...so I’m hedging my bets as to how mods will resolve this
I leave a few open for strategy.
And that's a no. Got this one wrong so let's see how much one day of being right helps my score.

A worker stands over molten steel at the Salzgitter AG steelworks on March 7, 2017 in Salzgitter, Germany.
Getty Images
A worker stands over molten steel at the Salzgitter AG steelworks on March 7, 2017 in Salzgitter, Germany.
The Trump administration will put tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from Canada, Mexico and the European Union, the latest action in a string of protectionist policies to crack down on alleged trade abuses. The tariffs of 25 percent on steel imports and 10 percent on aluminum imports will take effect at midnight Thursday, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross told reporters. The U.S. gave those allies a reprieve from those duties, but the exemptions were set to expire Friday. The Trump administration will place quotas or volume limits on other countries such as South Korea, Argentina, Australia and Brazil instead of tariffs, he said.
Stable genius has got this. Someone hold dear leader's beer. Where's Melania anyway?

Think Tank Stratfor https://www.facebook.com/stratfor/  has made a compelling narrative that because the NAFTA talks are ongoing, likely Mexico and Canada will get another exemption.  +25% for Temp YES.
US today started again on trade war with China. Ergo, there is a higher chance for NO on Mexico exemption. +6 to NO.
They have not cringed and caved in satisfactorily on NAFTA and will have to be punished.  This is the iron law of grade-school playground bullies.

Early hints that EU won't have the tariffs pushed back. What does this mean for Mexico?  Maybe +5% or +10% for NO? Unsure how to weight it.
https://www.ft.com/content/36cffdba-61b4-11e8-a39d-4df188287fff
WoC 60/30/10 Temp/No/Perm.  Never know, more Trumpy-Distractor Chaos coming.
Despite the appearances of the trump white house, continuity is almost always the safer bet. While NAFTA renegotiations go on I don't see steal tariffs being applied to Mexico or Canada.
CNBC reports DJT backed off China tariffs due to internal strife in WH. That increases the odds for Mexico as well.

NAFTA is the tool for a permanent exemption, so unlikely on that.  The deadline is looming for pushing a new NAFTA deal for this congress to approve in 2018, both Mexico and Canada see the calculus in delaying it past that deadline.  The administration sees the reasoning for not starting trade war prematurely thus extending the tariffs by a month, there seems good reasoning it will happen again as 1 month for negotiations was too short.

The Leader Of The Free World is deeply caring and merciful and no way racialist, and he will exempt them as soon as they:  Speak English exclusively; become overwhelmingly white; pay for his wall; and continue to work at Mar-Et-Cetera for $1.05 a day.   There is still a chance that some US firm that uses this product will agree to hold a massive, free-spending convention at one of his hotels every week for six months.  This will cause him to understand  the merits of the case and provide the exemption, which will be for six months, renewable until the conventions run out.

NAFTA talks just turned "south" and Trump's negotiating tactics appear to be that of the "make 'em say uncle" variety.  He'll dangle steel as a carrot and things may progress but not before 2 June 2018.

Most likely on a temporary basis as NAFTA negotiations continue. If they fall apart, and Trump perceives Mexico as precipitating the failure, he'll probably push forward on the tariffs. I don't really see a permanent exemption unless the NAFTA negotiations finish with an agreement Trump views as positive to his interest.
